title: Wayne Newton's Las Vegas estate opening as museum [Photos]
text:
Friday, September 18, 2015 09:43 AM EDT World's top celebrity museums Previous Next 
Casa de Shenandoah, Las Vegas: Wayne Newton's Las Vegas estate -- filled with luxurious gilded furniture, cars, a jet and a capuchin monkey -- has opened as a museum, with tour prices starting at $35. Fans start at the visitor's centre and then shuttle into the compound to see the iconic entertainer's memorabilia. (AP Photo/Julie Jacobson, File) 
Lucille Ball - Desi Arnaz Center for Comedy, Jamestown, New York: The legend that is Lucille Ball and "I Love Lucy" lives on at this Center for Comedy in Lucille's hometown of Jamestown. Educating and entertaining visitors with the life of Lucy and Desi though videos, pictures, memorabilia and costumes, this museum has been thrilling tourists since 1996. Exhibits are regularly changed, so there's always something new for Lucy fans who want to visit time and time again. (File Photo) 
Graceland, Memphis: The former home of Elvis is now a major Memphis tourist attraction, with more than 600,000 people visiting the home each year since it was opened as a museum in 1982. Graceland offers an audio-guided tour narrated by Elvis' daughter Lisa Marie. Check out his dining room, jungle room, racquetball building and giant trophy building, which houses his expansive collection of gold records, photographs and stage costumes. (Joe Warmington/Postmedia Network) 
The Anne Murray Centre, Springhill, Nova Scotia: Iconic Canadian singer Anne Murray is honoured with a museum in her hometown of Springhill, Nova Scotia. Showcasing awards won by Murray, as well as memorabilia, photos and videos of the singer, the Anne Murray Centre has welcomed more than 400,000 Murray fans from around the world since it opened in 1989. (Mike Drew/Postmedia Network) 
Madame Tussauds Wax Museums: Travellers who wish to get up-close with their favourite star never have to travel far to meet them, thanks to Madame Tussauds Wax Museums. The famous wax museums have small beginnings, with the first one opened by Marie Tussaud in London in 1835. There are still a few wax figures made by Marie herself in existence, including one of Benjamin Franklin. Today, sports stars, celebrities and politicians have all found themselves made over in wax for Tussauds' 15 locations around the world, from singers Lady Gaga and Alicia Keys to actors Robert Pattinson and Brad Pitt. (WENN.com photos) 
Andy Warhol Museum, Pittsburgh: The Andy Warhol Museum, located in the iconic artist's hometown of Pittsburgh, is a must-see for fans of Warhol's imaginative designs. Wander through seven floors of his colourful, eye-grabbing art; 1,000 Warhol prints, 100 sculptures and 4,000 photographs are housed in the building, a former warehouse. If you can't make it to Pittsburg, don't fret. The museum also organizes travelling shows of Warhol art that have been seen by more than 8 million people around the globe. (Handout/Christie's Images Limited) Reuters 
Hemingway Home and Museum, Key West, Florida: This U.S. National Historic Landmark was once home to author Ernest Hemingway himself. Today, the house serves as a tourist attraction and a museum of Hemingway history. Six and seven-toed cats, which guides say are descended from Hemingway's own cats, still roam the property. (Handout/Florida Keys News Bureau) Reuters 
Vulcan Tourism & Trek Station, Vulcan, Alberta: Thanks to its quirky name, which was actually bestowed on Vulcan by a Canadian Pacific Rail worker who named the town after the Roman god of fire, Vulcan has become a must-see destination for fans of Star Trek. The first Star Trek convention was held in the town in 1992, while the replica Starship arrived in town in 1995. The Vulcan Tourism and Trek Station opened in 1998, featuring memorabilia and items for purchase. Spock himself, Leonard Nimoy, visited Vulcan in 2010 shortly after the town became the official Star Trek Capital of Canada. (Postmedia Network) 
Britney Spears exhibit, Kentwood Historical and Cultural Arts Museum, Louisiana: The Kentwood Museum in Britney's hometown - population 2,205 - opened a small Britney exhibit to honour the town's most famous daughter. The exhibit features awards and platinum records earned by Britney, fan photos, documentation of past Britney Spears Days in Kentwood and even a replica of Britney's childhood bedroom, complete with framed photograph of Justin Timberlake. (FayesVision/WENN.com) 
Beatles Story, Liverpool, England: Four young English men forever changed the face of music when they took their rock sounds from Liverpool to the world. The Beatles Story museum in Liverpool pays homage to the Beatles' roots, taking visitors on a journey via memorabilia and audio guides from Liverpool to Abbey Road to the Yellow Submarine. The Beatles Story museum also offers tips for tours in Liverpool that will take you to other key Beatles' sites. (Courtesy Beatles Story) 
Newseum, Washington, D.C.: Even though Jon Stewart has said goodbye to 'The Daily Show,' travellers can still visit his set at Washington D.C.'s Newseum. The set was donated to the Newseum after Stewart's final episode in August 2015, including the desk, globe and props. (AP Photo/Evan Vucci, File)
